Several readers have asked this and several others have answered so I'll 
keep this brief

Let's say Candidate A has 50,000 votes and the quota for election is 
40,000, so he has 10,000 surplus votes.  If half his supporters (25,000 of 
them) marked Candidate D as their 2nd choice, 5,000 votes (half the 
surplus) have to be transferred to Candidate D.

There are two ways of doing this:

One is pick 5,000 of the 25,000 votes at random.  This is fair in a rough 
and ready way and will usually be reasonably fair if enough people have 
voted.

The other is to transfer all the 25,000 votes (for which D was 2nd choice) 
at a fraction of their value.  In this case, it is calculated as 25,000 
divided by 5,000; i.e. 1/5th (20%).  This is more accurate.

Some territories use one system and others use the other.

There are serious downsides to this system that maybe you could touch on in 
another video. Namely that with the removal of electoral districts it will 
be harder for a single candidate to reach out to voters without larger 
campaign funding. Trying to get elected from a district of 500 voters is 
far easier and less expensive then trying to get elected from a district 
with 500,000. What ends up happening is that the three candidates with the 
largest political war chest will end up in the congress (in the absence of 
personal familiarity with a candidate, voters will default to faux 
familiarity which is achieved through things like media and advertising), 
and those without the proper campaign financing will once again fall by the 
wayside. What we have with American democracy is a congress that is 
incredibly skilled at fundraising.

Fundraising is a valuable skill and requires many talents that people find 
meritorious, like leadership, public speaking, persuasion, drive, 
discipline and organizational ability, and the people and groups who give 
money to a candidate believe that that candidate can win and govern 
effectively. The question is whether we believe that the same skills used 
in fundraising are the same skills that make an effective legislator. If 
so, then the system we have in place is adequate. If not, then the solution 
is to eliminate the necessity of creating faux familiarity and force 
candidates to focus their efforts on voters who are not politically 
mobilized.

The average citizen's level of political mobilization ends with party 
affiliation. Most are not involved in other interest groups, whether they 
be grass roots organizations like home owners associations, private 
political blocs like big business lobbies, or other political organizations 
who can mobilize votes like public or private unions. The way to break the 
hold of these organizations (if that is your intent), is to make voting 
districts smaller, not larger. With smaller districts, less money is needed 
by candidates to familiarize themselves with the public, which means that 
they are more free to make policy which benefits the general, 
non-politically organized public, as opposed to special interest groups who 
finance their candidacies and by such hold their loyalty which may be 
opposed to the will of the people. Smaller districts increase the power of 
the individual vote and therefore increase the level of direct 
representation and voter accountability in the congress. 

By creating smaller districts, we also increase the size of the congress, 
which will further dilute the power of any power group within it, creating 
a much more representative and democratic legislature whose individual 
members are beholden to their smaller and more responsive districts. ﻿

You could probably look at the #2 votes of that range as a whole and run it 
as a winner-take-all election for the excess percentage, or look at the #2 
votes of the range as a whole and distribute the excess percentage points 
in proportion to the picks. In these instances, there would be no "cutoff 
point" -- rather, a mini election would be performed within that range to 
decide where the excess goes. In a way, everyone in that range would 
receive a second vote of sorts -- but the power of that second vote would 
be in proportion to the range as a whole. 

Let's say we have 100 voters just to keep the percentages clean. The 
choices are A, B, C, and D; they receive 60%, 5%. 30%, and 5%. A only needs 
33%, so is left with an excess 27% to distribute. As a whole, they voted 
66% for B, 30% for C, and 4% for D (which amounts to ~+18% for B, ~8% for

just an example). So, after the excess runs off, you end up with 23% for B, 
38% for C, and 6% for D. At this point, the runoffs get a little messy in

I hope you don’t mind if I restate the premise without the numbers.
Thesis
‘The flaw of the system lies in that a candidate that a majority like, but 
are unwilling to choose as a first choice, gets eliminated in favour of a 
candidate that has more first votes but is hated by a majority of the

Jump to Summary if you hate math

I will be using Percentage points to 3 decimal places so as to better 
simulate the situation (There was a fair bit of rounding up and down in my 
previous calculations).
Droop Method Threshold: 
Threshold %= ((100/ (n+1)) +1 
Where n=number of representatives to be chosen
In order to better simulate real life events, I will use 10 candidates and 
5 representatives 
Each ‘round’ ends when either a candidate becomes a representative OR a 
candidate is eliminated.
Candidate X is our protagonist (Well liked by a majority, few 1st votes).
Candidate Y is our antagonist (Hated by a majority, relatively many 1st 
votes).
The simulation ends when either X or Y is eliminated/promoted.
I will be assuming that the proportion of votes is the same for every 
sample of voters, and that there are no 3rd votes and so on (The maths 
becomes tricky if you involve 3rd votes).
(This is unlikely but at the same time, I don’t have the time to write a 
more complicated algorithm to deal with that)

A-31-24
B-29-29
C-12-05
D-07-05
E-02-03
F-03-00
G-02-01
H-03-00
X-04-32

Note: Not all voter have voted 2nd votes
Threshold = 17.667%
1st Round: A and B become representatives. 
2nd votes distributed from extra percentage points.
(Note: 2nd votes to A are obviously not counted when distributing extra 
votes of A)

From A,
New % points: B(34.156), C(12.889), D (7.889), E(2.533), F(03), G(2.178), 
H(03), X(9.678), Y(06)
From B,
New % points:  C (14.681), D(9.681), E(3.609), F(3), G(2.53), H(03), 
X(21.137), Y(06)

So, it would seem that the thesis is wrong.

However, that is considering a case where 2 candidates hold a majority of

>>>Summary<<<

I did some more simulations and it seems that the following conditions seem 
to favour someone who’s hated by a majority of voters:

only to those candidates. E.g The 20 1st voters for A give their 2nd votes

This situation is likely to arise when popular parties field candidates

4.The number of representatives is lowered.

It seems to me that you are mistaken in how the election

candidate E would be eliminated, despite having the greatest

For the situation favorable to e, all 40 of the 1st voters

votes

 Thus using the droop method, there is no way that candidate E would be the

One way around it is to lower the threshold slightly. Many STV elections 
set their threshold lower than the video suggests: rather than dividing 
100% by the number of candidates, you divide by one more than the number of 
candidates. So for three candidates, you divide by four and only need to 
get over 25% instead of 33%.

one person's got (just over) 25%, and another, and another, you're *over* 
75% and there is slightly less than 25% left.  So there aren't enough votes 
remaining for a fourth person to cross the threshold. And that spare 25% 
(or whatever proportion) acts as something of a bin for the wasted votes 
(those people who don't express a second preference, etc.). Lowering the 
threshold makes it less likely that there will be enough of those to spoil 
things.

parties, most of whom fielded a couple of Senator candidates in the 
election.

What about a system using variable positive/negative voting? Voters would 
be allowed to vote for every candidate using a -3,+3 range. This allows for 
people to give votes to their second and third choices without sacrificing 
their support for their favorite candidate. It also helps to depolarize the 
political landscape, since extreme candidates would receive many more -3 
votes and could then be defeated by more moderate candidates who have a 
smaller +3 support group, but receive much fewer negative votes. It would 
also give valuable statistical information about the polarization of the 
voting population. In the worst case with this system, voters would give 
their first candidate +3 and all other candidates -3, making it exactly the 
same as a single vote system. Another point in favor of this system is that 
it does not assume that every voter values their second choice equally. In 
a normal ranked voting, all second choices receive equal weighting, but in 
this system, one voter could give their top choice +3 and their second 
choice +2, while another voter gives their first choice +3 and their second 
choice -2. Here we see that even though both people may order their choices 
the same, the second person dislikes the second choice with the same 
magnitude as the first person likes the second choice.﻿

captions.text:
Queen Lion is looking to make the elections
in her animal kingdom more fair. Currently

she divides her citizens into ranges each
of which selects one representative to go

to the jungle council which makes laws for
the kingdom.

But her citizens are unhappy, and it's easy
to see why: the council is full of monkeys.

Of course some of her citizens are monkeys,
but not all of them. This council doesn't
fairly represent her kingdom.

Queen lion visits one of the ranges to find
out what's wrong and how to fix it.

In this range there five monkeys, four tigers,
three owls, two lynx and one buffalo. One

of each runs for representative and all citizens
vote for their own species.

The election rule is that the candidate with
the most votes wins, which is the monkey.

But it's a pretty unsatisfying result considering
that 2/3rds of citizens in this range *aren't*
monkeys and wouldn't vote for monkeys.

This is the same across all the ranges of
the kingdom, the monkeys have more votes than

anybody else, so they win all the elections,
even though they are a minority of the total

population. Closer inspection reveals that
the independent advisors hired to draw the

range boundaries in the first place weren't
as independent as they first appeared.

The result is unhappy citizens who don't trust
the jungle council to make the fairest laws
for all, quite rightly.

Now Queen lion wants to maximize the number
of citizens happy with the election results.

One way to do that is to abolish the ranges
and use a proportional system... ...But her
citizens *want* local representatives.

So Queen lion needs a system that both make
her citizens happier by having a more representative
council while keeping local elections in place.

After doing a little research she finds out
how: Single Transferable Vote.

The big change with STV is that ranges send
more than one representative, which may seem

weird, but queen lion decides to test it out:
she takes three ranges which used to each

send one representative and combines them
into one bigger range that will send three.

On election day citizens go to the polls and
the results in this new range are just the

same as they were in the old ranges: 34% for
Monkey, 33% for Owl and 33% for Lynx.

But this isn't most votes wins: with STV to
figure out the winners take the total votes

and divide by the number of representatives
needed, in this case 3 which gives 33% as
the amount a candidates needs to win.

So *all three* candidates go to the council
-- which accurately represents the citizens
in the range.

Whereas under the old system each range would
have sent a monkey. Leaving 2/3rd of the citizens

without representation. A bigger range with
more representatives allows the range to be
more proportional.

This test turned out well, but it was also
as simple as could be -- now Queen Lion wants

to see what happens in a race where not everyone
is a winner.

The next big range she tests has five candidates
running for office: Gorilla, Tasier, Monkey,
Tiger, and Lynx, three of which can be representatives.

Election day comes and goes, and here are
the results of citizens first choices:

Tasier gets 5%
Gorilla gets 28%

Monkey gets 33%
Tiger gets 21%
Lynx gets 13%

As before, a candidate needs 33% to win. Monkey
has that as so is immediately selected as
one of the three representatives.

But no one else reached the winning 33% so
how are the other two representatives selected?

Step one: get rid of the biggest loser. Sorry
tasier -- you really had no chance at all.

Now, when the citizens voted, they could have
just put an X next to the candidate they liked

most but with STV they can also rank their
favorite candidates. This is important because

it shows how the election would have turned
out if one of the candidates hadn't run.

Tiny and Worried Tasiers would have voted
for the big calm gorilla without tasier in

the race. So if their candidate can't win,
they want their votes to go to Gorilla instead.

This pushes gorilla up to 33% and he become
the next representative.

Ranking allows citizens to support their favorite
candidate without worry -- there's no point

in strategizing about how everyone else is
going to vote. The system works to maximize
voter happiness with the result.

Back to the range: there's still one representative
to select, so the next biggest loser is Lynx.

His voters don't like simians, but they do
think tiger's interests are similar to theirs

and so if Lynx can't win they want him to
have their votes. Tiger gets reaches 33% and
becomes the third and final representative.

The election result looks pretty good especially
considering citizens first *and* second choices.

Now more citizens have a local representative
they can feel comfortable approaching, whereas
using the old system, everybody gets a monkey.

Lastly queen lion wants know what happens
in a range with just two political parties.

Under the most-votes-wins systems, multiple
candidates from the same party would be a

disaster: they'd split their voters and hand
the win to their opposition.

Queen lion makes one last test range with
2/3rd tigers and 1/3 gorillas that as before,
needs three representatives.

Because with STV citizens rank their candidates
there can be more than one candidate running
at the same time without any problems.
The tigers run two candidates as do the gorillas.

White tiger becomes the first representative,
but what happens next? While tiger seems to

be the biggest loser, it's also obvious that
he would have gotten way more votes if white

tiger wasn't in the race. If a candidate has
more votes than they need, like white tiger

does, the first step is to give the extra
votes to their second choice. This gets tiger
to 33% and he becomes the next representative.

If that seems strange, there are two things
to consider:

1) If instead the extra votes were ignored,
and tiger eliminated then the gorillas would

get the remaining two wins, which would obviously
not be represent the range.

2) Ignoring these 'extra' votes is punishing
citizens who backed the popular candidate,

which makes voters start thinking about how
everyone else will vote, rather than what

they really want. If a candidate gets extra
votes in the first place it also means that

those who voted for him are a big section
of the population and thus fairly should get
more representation.

Right: after the extra votes go to tiger,
the election finishes as before: Silverback

came in last, is eliminated and his voters'
second choice is the younger candidate so
gorilla gets in. And the results are fair.

Queen Lion has now seen STV work. Whether
a range has one party or lots the process
is still the same:

1. Citizens rank their favorite candidates.
2. Any candidate above the threshold wins

immediately,
3. 'Extra' votes go to their next choice.

4. If no winner, last place is eliminated,
and the votes to go their next choice.
5. Repeat until all the winners are found.

This whole this process is designed to maximize
the number of citizens who are happy with
the result.

This process gives STV has many advantages
over the old, most-votes-wins system:

1. Citizens can honestly vote for their favorite
candidate without worrying about what everyone

else is going to do.
2. It's more proportional. So monkeying with

the borders matters less.
3. Almost all citizens will have a local representative
they actually voted for.

In the end Queen lion decides to switch the
council's elections to Single Transferable
Vote to make a better jungle council for all.

title: Politics in the Animal Kingdom: Single Transferable Vote
